svg.title: revised-redox-tower
svg.text: Redox couples and potentials (mV) for elements common in biology at pH 7 and temperature 25 C *

Redox potential indicates the propensity for a compound to transfer electrons to another compound. A more-negative redox potential means a compound is more likely to donate electrons (e-). All of life gets its energy by capturing the change in potential energy from the transfer of electrons from the reducing compound to the oxidizing compound.
Reactive oxidants not used in energy metabolism, often toxic
Not shown: electron carrying cofactors, Br, I, Te, Ag, Au, Pd, Hg, Cr, V, Mo, Tc, various Fe minerals, various organics.
Examples of energetically favorable redox metabolisms
* For teaching purposes only. Consult the scientific literature for exact values.
Energy must be spent to fix carbon dioxide

In phototrophy, light increases the potential for an electron to reduce other compounds. In this case, with light, electrons from sulfide can be used to fix carbon dioxide without spending energy. This also allows different molecules to serve as electron donors. The evolution of photosystem II in cyanobacteria allowed water to be oxidized to oxygen.
The small difference in redoxpotentials provides little energy.
Denitrification involves several electronacceptors with varying redox potentials.
Oxygen is an excellent electron acceptor. Multicellular life almost always needs oxygen.
The electron acceptor in fermentation is the partially oxidized electron donor. While often a back-upmetabolism, many microbes use only fermentation for energy.
